awd_titl_txt: RUI: Spatially-Resolved Kinematics of Reverberation-Mapped Active Galactic Nuclei Host Galaxies
awd_abstract_narration:
Part 1

Most galaxies harbor in their center a very massive black hole with a mass that can range from millions to billions of times the mass of the Sun. They are also known as supermassive black holes. The origin of supermassive black holes is an important open question in astronomy. For supermassive black holes growing through accretion of dust and gas in the centers of so-called "active galaxies", their mass can be measured through an observing technique known as "echo mapping". In this work, the PI will study the properties of the host galaxies for a sample of 33 active galaxies for which the mass of the supermassive black hole has been previously determined through echo mapping. They have obtained data with some of the largest telescopes world-wide, the Keck telescope (Hawaii) and the Very Large Telescope (Chile). Their state-of-the art instruments allow the PI to measure spectra (the distribution of light over different wavelengths, similar to a rainbow) over the entire galaxy within one single observation. They will study the relationship between the mass of the supermassive black hole and the kinematics of the stars in the galaxy, a measure of the galaxy mass. The tightness of such a relationship indicates that supermassive black holes and galaxies grow together. Their sample extends existing relationships into the high mass regime and can be used to study trends with mass and galaxy morphology. This will enhance understanding of the growth and evolution of supermassive black holes and galaxies. While echo mapping is time consuming, its results have enabled black-hole mass estimates for active galaxies across the universe. The PI's sample will serve as a calibrator for these black-hole mass measurements. 


Part 2

Supermassive Black Holes are very massive black holes in the center of galaxies with millions to billions of times the mass of the Sun. The origin of supermassive black holes is an important open question in astronomy. For supermassive black holes growing through accretion of dust and gas in the centers of so-called "active galaxies", their mass can be measured through an observing technique known as "echo mapping". In this work, the PI will study the properties of the host galaxies for a sample of 33 active galaxies for which the mass of the supermassive black hole has been previously determined through echo mapping. They have obtained data with some of the largest telescopes world-wide, the Keck telescope (Hawaii) and the Very Large Telescope (Chile). Their state-of-the art instruments allow the PI to measure spectra over the entire galaxy within one single observation. They will study the relationship between the mass of the supermassive black hole and the kinematics of the stars in the galaxy, a measure of the galaxy mass. The tightness of such a relationship indicates that supermassive black holes and galaxies grow together. In addition, they will fit images (either created from the spectra or taken by the Hubble Space Telescope) for a detailed host-galaxy decomposition. The sample extends existing relationships into the high mass regime and can be used to study trends with mass and galaxy morphology. This will enhance understanding of the growth and evolution of supermassive black holes and galaxies. While echo mapping is time consuming, its results have enabled black-hole mass estimates for active galaxies across the universe. The PI's sample will serve as a calibrator for these black-hole mass measurements.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit

The research supported by this grant focuses on active galaxies, i.e., galaxies in which the massive black hole (BH) in the center is growing through accretion. These objects are also referred to as Active Galactic Nuclei (AGNs). The research studies relations between the mass of the central BH and the properties of the host galaxy which indicate a close link between the formation and evolution of BHs and galaxies. We selected a unique sample of AGNs for which the mass of the BH had been previously determined to high accuracy using a technique known as reverberation mapping (RM). To study their host galaxies in great detail, integral-field spectroscopy was obtained from state-of-the-art instruments at the W. M. Keck Observatory (Hawaii) and the Very Large Telescope (Chile). Images were obtained with the Hubble Space Telescope and analyzed using state-of-the-art software "lenstronomy". Combining the spatially-resolved kinematics with high-resolution images provides the most robust BH mass-host-galaxy scaling relations of RM AGNs in the Universe. The final sample consists of ~50 AGNs with a wide range of AGN and host-galaxy properties. We show that rotational broadening is the primary source of systematic uncertainty for measuring stellar-velocity dispersion in late-type galaxies. After correcting for disk rotation and selection bias, the slope and intrinsic scatter of the AGN relation aligns with those of quiescent galaxies. Our sample forms the crucial low-z anchor for the determination of MBH in AGNs throughout the Universe.

PI Bennert was also involved in a couple of reverberation mapping campaigns, the Lick AGN Monitoring Project and the Seoul AGN Monitoring Project, using the 3m Shane telescope of Lick Observatory for spectroscopy and the 1m Nickel telescope for photometry. Measurements of broad hydrogen emission time lags significantly increase the current RM AGN sample, especially at the moderate-to-high-luminosity end. Velocity-resolved lag measurements indicate a diversity of BLR gas kinematics and BLR structure. Relations between the virial coefficient and other AGN or BLR properties may be used to better constrain BH masses using the single-epoch method. In addition, a couple of infrared RM campaigns were conducted using NASA's Infrared Telescope Facility (Hawaii), focusing on AGNs for which the GRAVITY collaboration recently spatially resolved the broad-line region directly.

Results have been published in 20 scientific papers.

Broader Impact

PI Bennert included 8 undergraduate students in this research. Students were directly exposed to the scientific methodology by learning
how to observe with professional telescopes and by carrying out self-contained research projects. All students have given talks and poster presentations at numerous occasions at Cal Poly, and at the American Astronomical Society (AAS) Meeting. Students were also involved in public outreach and attended several family STEM nights at local elementary school and brought hands-on astronomy demos. PI Bennert was also a co-supervisor for a handful of PhD students at various universities.

PI Bennert established the Learning Assistant (LA) program in Astronomy the PI's host institution, the California Polytechnic State University in San Luis Obispo (Cal Poly). LAs are undergraduate students who interact with students in the class during the active parts and facilitate group interactions by asking students questions to help them make progress. LAs have taken the class previously, and receive special concurrent preparation, both on content, as well as on effective STEM pedagogy. The LA program has been proven to be a very effective STEM teacher pipeline. PI Bennert helped spread the usage of LAs in STEM disciplines at Cal Poly by mentoring and advising faculty in best practices on involving LAs in their classes.

PI Bennert offered 12 workshops on mindfulness and work-life balance at Cal Poly to help students make healthy daily choices for a general improvement of well-being. PI Bennert was the lead planner and organizer of the on-campus public viewing of the partial solar eclipses visible from San Luis Obispo. A handful of other faculty as well as students and staff helped with the viewing. The events were a total success and attended by hundreds of people.

In all her efforts, PI Bennert has been actively promoting the participation of underrepresented minorities. She has served as a Cal Bridge mentor and the liaison between Cal Poly Physics and Cal-Bridge. She has also continued her own professional development through attending various workshops focusing on diversity, equity and inclusion (e.g., an inclusive mentoring training workshop).

For broad dissemination of the results, PI Bennert presented her research at numerous occasions, including an invited review talk at the International Astronomical Union (August 2022, Korea), and at the AAS (January 2024, New Orleans).
